Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the actual logic is fully decentralized

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: an nSPV client will reject any node that doesnt provide nSPV services

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nSPV branch enables nSPV services for fullnodes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so with the p2p networking having a few nSPV enabled fullnodes, eventually the nSPV node will find them, of course much more efficient to just point them at one directly

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: ok im trying to reverse it now and test that myself

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: after majority of people update to nSPV enabled nodes, then most any node will provide nSPV services, so this state of sparse nSPV support is just during testing

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the cool part is that we are able to test nSPV with the live mainnet, without disrupting it at all

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and basically all full nodes perform function similar to electrum servers, automaticallly

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and of course the data set it fine tuned to be 1000x more efficient than an SPV headers only client

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: well, wondering if nSPV has support for shielded transactions

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nspv is about proving a txid happened or not

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: shielded txid ?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: proven via notarizations, merkleroots

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: txid is a hash of the raw tx bytes, so you can prove a specific txid exists

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the problem is what txids need to be proven?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and then given the rawtx, how will you process it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: that is the layer above nspv

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: how does zSPV and nSPV interact, if at all?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nSPV would be the transport layer

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the big giant issue with zSPV is that nobody knows which txid belongs to which node...

Author: daemonfox#6136
Content: oh god my heads gonna explode zSPV

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so short of syncing the entire chain and trying to decrypt each one, you cant know which txid you want

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: however...

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if the sender can tell you the txid, say using a taddr opreturn with encrypted payload

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes, that sounds interesting

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: then we can get a taddr/zaddr nSPV solution!
